data.message: Are there any concerns with weather taking this thing down?

replies.message: Hi Nick. Safety is a top priority for our team as we build Aquila. It's early days and we need to make sure the technology works first. We can assure you this is something we are thinking about and that our team and our testing will address. -Jordan
I guess just avoid the Bermuda triangle haha good luck
Flying at 90,000 feet during daylight and gliding to 60,000 feet at night, the aircraft should be well above most weather
Can you control were it comes down so that it doesn't harm anyone?

How long  before it disintegrates and what is the possibility that this aircraft will malfunction and land in someone's backyard  and create mayhem? Remember free falling plus gravity makes it a deadly weapon.
i'm sure to act as a repeater for data transmission it doesn't need to take a path DIRECTLY over residential areas, i'm sure they would be able to avoid them all together most likely
Amazing! What about air traffic control and how does it land?
What about homeland security and providing terrorists a way to tap into possible pertinant information via this plane??
Thats right.and how about Air Space Clearance especially china,south korea,north korea.all of these third world countries will shoot this plane down.
How far is the access of the plane provide like does it cover an area of 1000 miles,  and has to stay in that area?  And this is strictly wifi?  Facebook?
An incredible step forward but as a pilot I wonder if today's batteries can support extended flight and two, what country will be the first to shoot it down for "snooping"
From 80000 feet daytime and 68000 feet at night. At that altitude, would there be air space violation?

How long  before it disintegrates and what is the possibility that this aircraft will malfunction and land in someone's backyard  and create mayhem? Remember free falling plus gravity makes it a deadly weapon.
To Kharleau Daymust for them to get a space violation they have to fly under 60,000 feet or lower and communication  from the glider to each tower is constant

It flies over oceans and islands not land masses that are connected to the grid so crashlanding in a backyard???
No likely the ocean more likely
Remember its mission to connect remote locations not able to recieve cable
How is it controlled?
How much time will they have on Facebook when it's in the area?
How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could Chuck wood??
Thank you  Joey Yost for your point of clarification. What about my other concerns?

How long  before it disintegrates and what is the possibility that this aircraft will malfunction and land in someone's backyard  and create mayhem? Remember free falling plus gravity makes it a deadly weapon.
Chuck Mercier - the video says its solar powered so I assume the batteries would be recharged during the day and have sufficient charge to power the aircraft during the night hours.
When designing started everything is considered.. positively
Facebook
